subject: Physical Science
overview: Chapter 3, 'Coal and Petroleum,' is centrally focused on exhaustible natural resources, specifically the fossil fuels that power much of our modern world. This review covers their classification, formation, constituent products, and the critical need for conservation.

content.introduction: Natural resources, which include air, water, soil, and minerals, are categorized based on their availability in nature:

keyPoints.title: Inexhaustible Natural Resources
keyPoints.description: Present in unlimited quantity and unlikely to be exhausted by human activities.

keyPoints.title: Exhaustible Natural Resources
keyPoints.description: The amount present in nature is limited, and they can be exhausted by human activities.

content.introduction: Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are collectively known as fossil fuels because they were formed from the dead remains of living organisms (fossils) over millions of years.

keyPoints.title: Coal Formation (Carbonisation)
keyPoints.description: Approximately 300 million years ago, dense forests were buried under soil due to natural processes like flooding. Under high pressure and high temperature, the dead vegetation slowly converted into coal, which mainly consists of carbon. This process is called carbonisation.
subPoints: Dense forests buried under soil due to flooding
High pressure and high temperature conditions
Dead vegetation converted to coal over millions of years

keyPoints.title: Petroleum Formation
keyPoints.description: Formed from organisms living in the sea. When these organisms died, their bodies settled at the bottom and were covered by layers of sand and clay. Over millions of years, the absence of air, along with high temperature and pressure, transformed these remains into petroleum and natural gas.
subPoints: Bodies covered by sand and clay layers
Absence of air crucial for formation
High temperature and pressure over millions of years
Oil and gas are lighter than water - found layered above water deposits

content.introduction: Fossil fuels undergo processing in industries to yield many useful products:

keyPoints.title: Coal Products
keyPoints.description: When coal is processed, it yields three main products:

subPoints.name: Coke
subPoints.definition: A tough, porous, and black substance that is an almost pure form of carbon. Used in the manufacture of steel and the extraction of many metals.

subPoints.name: Coal Tar
subPoints.definition: A thick, black liquid with an unpleasant smell, consisting of about 200 substances. Used as starting material for synthetic dyes, drugs, plastics, paints, and even naphthalene balls. (Note: Bitumen, a petroleum product, is now used for surfacing roads instead of coal tar).

subPoints.name: Coal Gas
subPoints.definition: Obtained during the processing of coal to get coke. It is primarily used as a source of heat for industries.

keyPoints.title: Petroleum Products (Refining)
keyPoints.description: Petroleum is a mixture of various constituents. The process of separating these constituents is called refining, which occurs in a petroleum refinery.

subPoints.name: Diesel
subPoints.definition: Fuel for heavy motor vehicles and electric generators.

subPoints.name: Kerosene
subPoints.definition: Fuel for stoves, lamps, and jet aircraft.

subPoints.name: Bitumen
subPoints.definition: Used for paints and road surfacing.

examples: Petroleum is called 'black gold' due to its great commercial importance
Petrochemicals: Substances derived from petroleum and natural gas used for manufacturing synthetic fibers and plastics

keyPoints.title: Natural Gas
keyPoints.description: Natural gas is a very important fossil fuel because it is easy to transport through pipes and is less polluting.
subPoints: Stored under high pressure as Compressed Natural Gas (CNG)
Used as a cleaner fuel for transport vehicles
examples: CNG buses and vehicles produce less pollution than petrol/diesel vehicles

content.introduction: Fossil fuels are exhaustible resources, and their known reserves will last only a few hundred years. Their use is also linked to major environmental problems:

keyPoints.title: Environmental Problems
keyPoints.description: The use of fossil fuels causes significant environmental issues:
subPoints: Air Pollution: Burning fossil fuels releases pollutants
Global Warming: Their use is linked to global warming

keyPoints.title: Conservation Measures
keyPoints.description: We must use fossil fuels judiciously and only when absolutely necessary. Conservation tips while driving include:
subPoints: Driving at a constant and moderate speed
Switching off the engine at traffic lights or when waiting
examples: Turn off engine at red lights to save fuel
Proper tire pressure improves fuel efficiency

keyTakeaway.title: Future Responsibility
keyTakeaway.content: Fossil fuels are like a bank account of stored sunshine, established over millennia. Since we are rapidly depleting this fixed account, wise consumption today ensures that future generations are not left bankrupt and burdened by pollution.

chapterSummary: This chapter establishes that coal, petroleum, and natural gas are exhaustible fossil fuels formed over millions of years from dead organisms. While they provide numerous valuable products (coke, tar, LPG, petrol, diesel, etc.) that power modern civilization, their limited reserves and environmental impact (air pollution, global warming) make conservation and judicious use critically important for future generations.
